questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 4-day history of painful lesions in the mouth. During the past year, he has twice had similar lesions that resolved without treatment after approximately 10 days. He has never had any genital or anal lesions. His mother reports that he has been very stressed over the past month because he is approaching his senior year in high school. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He appears thin. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). A photograph of the oral cavity is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A common initial manifestation of pemphigus vulgaris is painful oral blisters that eventually ulcerate. Most patients also develop blisters on other body parts, but recurrent episodes of pemphigus vulgaris can occur without any associated cutaneous lesions (mucosal pemphigus vulgaris). However, the oral ulcers of pemphigus vulgaris typically have irregular margins, unlike the well-defined ovoid lesions seen here. Moreover, pemphigus vulgaris most commonly develops in older patients (40–60 years of age), and the lesions typically do not resolve without treatment.
Image Description:

Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral candidiasis typically manifests as painless, cream-white lesions of the tongue, buccal mucosa, or palate and occurs in individuals with risk factors such as immunosuppression (e.g., HIV infection), antibiotic therapy, corticosteroid use, xerostomia, and diabetes mellitus. Painful erosions of the labial mucosa in an otherwise healthy adolescent suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.

These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpangina typically affects children and adolescents and can manifest as painful oral erosions surrounded by an erythematous halo, which is seen here. However, the lesions typically occur on the palate and posterior pharyngeal wall, not the labial mucosa. Moreover, patients with herpangina are typically febrile and present with throat pain. Following an episode of herpangina, individuals become immune to the infecting group A coxsackievirus strain but can develop a recurrent attack of herpangina as a result of infection by a different virus strain.
Image Description:

Several small vesicles and partially confluent yellow-white ulcers with an erythematous rim are visible on the inflamed soft palate.

This is the typical appearance of herpangina, an infection caused by the coxsackie A virus. The enanthem typically starts as painful, herpes-like vesicles on the oropharynx that then break down to form shallow, painful ulcers.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes of the lips or oral mucosa manifests with painful blisters that eventually ulcerate. Following the primary infection, herpes stomatitis can recur during periods of stress, which is seen here. However, the lesions of recurrent herpes stomatitis typically occur on keratinized parts of the mouth and oral cavity, such as attached gingiva, the hard palate, and the vermillion border of the lip. The location of this patient's lesions on nonkeratinized areas such as the labial mucosa suggests a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles on an erythematous base can be seen on the lower lip.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpes labialis.

E) CORRECT:

Aphthous stomatitis is a common condition that manifests as painful, oral mucosal ulcers with regular margins, a yellow fibrinous base, and a surrounding erythematous halo. The lesions occur in parts of the oral cavity with nonkeratinized mucosa, such as the buccal and labial mucosae, the floor of the mouth, and the ventral surface of the tongue. The lesions typically resolve without treatment within 10–14 days but can recur during periods of acute stress.

F) INCORRECT:

Oral leukoplakia manifests as a white adherent plaque on the oral mucosa. It is a slowly growing, painless premalignant lesion and is usually seen in middle-aged or older patients with a history of tobacco use disorder.
Image Description:

Poorly demarcated, white plaque on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off.

This finding is most consistent with oral leukoplakia, which may develop into squamous cell carcinoma.
questions.hint: The image shows two ovoid erosions with regular margins and surrounding erythema on the labial mucosa.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man reports a 10-day history of a painful ulcer on the lateral aspect of his tongue. He had a similar episode 8 months ago that resolved spontaneously after 1 to 2 weeks. His sister has also had similar lesions in the past. The patient works in an indoor office and lives with his same-sex partner. He has not had a fever, eye symptoms, diarrhea, or genital ulcers.
On examination, he has a round ulcer on the left lateral aspect of his tongue (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scurvy is generally associated with multiple ulcers and other skin manifestations.

B) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease is unlikely in a patient with no complaints of abdominal pain or diarrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

The oral ulcers associated with HIV infection do not tend to resolve quickly and spontaneously. These shallow, painful lesions can be found not only on the oral mucosa but also on the anus, penis, or esophagus. They often occur with primary HIV infection and would be associated with other manifestations of acute HIV.

D) CORRECT:

Aphthous stomatitis, the most common cause of mouth ulcers, manifests as recurrent, painful, round ulcers with a gray, shallow base; they usually appear on the buccal mucosa and the tongue. This condition usually begins in adolescence or early adulthood, and the frequency decreases with age. The etiology is not well defined, but a family tendency is frequently reported.

Recurrent aphthous ulcers can occur in association with celiac disease, Crohn disease, Behçet syndrome, HIV infection, immunodeficiency syndromes, and nutritional deficiencies. Patients with ulcers attributable to these conditions tend to have other symptoms and manifestations of the underlying condition.

Key learning point: Recurrent ulcers on the buccal mucosa and the tongue that are round, shallow, and have a gray base are most consistent with a diagnosis of aphthous stomatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex infection is characterized by multiple painful ulcers, skin lesions, and vesicles.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a 4-day history of oral pain interfering with eating and speaking. He has experienced 5 or 6 similar episodes over the past 18 months. Examination findings are shown. Vital signs are normal, and he appears well. His medical history is significant for iron deficiency anemia that is currently being treated. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Aphthous stomatitis requires symptomatic treatment because no causal treatment is available. Topical anesthetics like lidocaine provide effective pain relief for these painful ulcers. The recurrent nature, characteristic appearance, and association with iron deficiency support this diagnosis. Other supportive treatments include topical corticosteroids and antimicrobials.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiviral therapy is not indicated for aphthous stomatitis, which is not caused by viral infections. The round ulcers with yellow-gray centers and recurrent pattern are characteristic of aphthous stomatitis, not herpes simplex virus lesions.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical nystatin is not indicated for aphthous stomatitis, which is not caused by fungal infection. Oral candidiasis manifests with white plaques that can be scraped off, whereas aphthous ulcers have characteristic yellow-gray centers with erythematous borders. The recurrent pattern and typical ulcer morphology are diagnostic of aphthous stomatitis, not candidal infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Chlorhexidine mouthwash is not indicated for aphthous stomatitis. While chlorhexidine has antiseptic properties and is used for periodontal disease and postoperative oral care, it does not provide specific benefit for aphthous ulcers and may cause mucosal irritation.

E) INCORRECT:

Tissue biopsy is not necessary for typical aphthous ulcers with characteristic clinical features. The round to oval appearance with yellow-gray centers, erythematous borders, and recurrent nature are diagnostic. Biopsy is only considered if atypical features are present.
